ü§ñ Source Generators

Zero-allocation, compile-time BSON mappers with no reflection overhead. Robust handling of nested objects, collections, and ref structs.

How It Works

BLite uses Roslyn Source Generators to create optimized serialization code at compile-time. This eliminates reflection overhead and enables zero-allocation I/O with correct handling of complex type hierarchies.

‚ú® Automatic: Generators activate automatically when you add the BLite package. No configuration needed!

Supported Attributes

Mapping Attributes

using System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations;
using System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations.Schema;
using System.Text.Json.Serialization;

[Table("users")]  // Collection name
public class User
{
    [Key]  // Primary key
    public ObjectId Id { get; set; }
    
    [Column("full_name")]  // Custom BSON field name
    public string Name { get; set; }
    
    [JsonPropertyName("email_address")]  // Also supported
    public string Email { get; set; }
    
    [JsonIgnore]  // Exclude from BSON
    public string TemporaryData { get; set; }
}

Validation Attributes

public class Product
{
    [Required]
    [StringLength(200, MinimumLength = 3)]
    public string Name { get; set; }
    
    [Range(0.01, 999999.99)]
    public decimal Price { get; set; }
    
    [EmailAddress]
    public string ContactEmail { get; set; }
    
    [Url]
    public string Website { get; set; }
}

Generated Code

For each model, BLite generates a mapper class:

// Generated automatically
internal class UserMapper : IBsonMapper<User>
{
    public void Serialize(User value, Span<byte> buffer)
    {
        // Zero-allocation serialization
    }
    
    public User Deserialize(ReadOnlySpan<byte> buffer)
    {
        // Zero-allocation deserialization
    }
}

Supported Types

  • Primitives: int, long, double, decimal, bool, string
  • Temporal Types: DateTime, DateTimeOffset, TimeSpan, DateOnly, TimeOnly
  • Collections: List<T>, T[], Dictionary<string, T>
  • BLite Types: ObjectId, BsonDocument
  • Nested Objects: Automatic recursive mapping
  • Enums: Serialized as integers or strings

Custom BSON Field Names

BLite follows a lowercase convention by default. Override with attributes:

public class Person
{
    // BSON field: "firstname" (lowercase)
    public string FirstName { get; set; }
    
    // BSON field: "family_name" (custom)
    [Column("family_name")]
    public string LastName { get; set; }
}

Base Entity Pattern with Nullable Ids

BLite correctly handles nullable Id properties inherited from generic base classes:

// Generic base entity
public abstract class BaseEntity<TId, TEntity>
{
    [Key]
    public virtual TId? Id { get; set; }
}

// Specialized base for string Ids
public abstract class UuidEntity<TEntity> : BaseEntity<string, TEntity>
{
}

// Concrete entity with nullable string Id
public class Counter : UuidEntity<Counter>
{
    public string Name { get; set; }
    public int Value { get; set; }
}
üí° Note: The generator automatically selects the correct base mapper class (StringMapperBase) even when Id is nullable (string?), ensuring type-safe serialization across inheritance hierarchies.

Performance Benefits

  • ‚úÖ Zero reflection - All mapping is compile-time
  • ‚úÖ Zero allocation - Direct Span<byte> operations
  • ‚úÖ Type safety - Compile errors instead of runtime failures
  • ‚úÖ Automatic validation - DataAnnotations checked on insert/update

Nested Objects & Collections

BLite generators correctly handle deeply nested object graphs, collections, and ref structs:

public class Address
{
    public string Street { get; set; }
    public string City { get; set; }
    public (double Lat, double Lng) Coordinates { get; set; }
}

public class Order
{
    public ObjectId Id { get; set; }
    public List<string> Tags { get; set; }
}

public class Customer
{
    [Key]
    public ObjectId Id { get; set; }
    
    public string Name { get; set; }
    
    // Nested object - automatically mapped
    public Address ShippingAddress { get; set; }
    
    // Collection of nested objects - fully supported
    public List<Order> Orders { get; set; }
    
    // Nested collections
    public Dictionary<string, List<int>> Metadata { get; set; }
}
‚ú® Recent Improvements (v1.3.0 ‚Äì v1.5.0):
  • ‚úÖ v1.5.0 ‚Äî Projection push-down: .Select(x => new Dto(x.F1, x.F2)) compiles to a single-pass BSON reader ‚Äî T is never allocated
  • ‚úÖ v1.5.0 ‚Äî WHERE + SELECT combined push-down evaluated in one BSON pass
  • ‚úÖ v1.5.0 ‚Äî IBLiteQueryable<T> preserves async LINQ chain across all operators; AsAsyncEnumerable() extension
  • ‚úÖ v1.5.0 ‚Äî FindAsync(predicate, ct) on DocumentCollection
  • ‚úÖ v1.4.0 ‚Äî Full async read path: FindByIdAsync, FindAllAsync, LINQ async extensions (ToListAsync, CountAsync, AnyAsync, ‚Ä¶)
  • ‚úÖ v1.4.0 ‚Äî BLiteEngine + DynamicCollection for schema-less BSON queries without compile-time types
  • ‚úÖ v1.3.0 ‚Äî Full temporal type support: DateTimeOffset, TimeSpan, DateOnly, TimeOnly
  • ‚úÖ v1.3.0 ‚Äî Improved nullable property handling in generated deserializers
  • ‚úÖ v1.3.0 ‚Äî Nullable string Id properties inherited from base classes (BaseEntity<string, T>)
  • ‚úÖ Property inheritance from base classes
  • ‚úÖ Private and init-only setters via Expression Trees
  • ‚úÖ Advanced collection types (IEnumerable<T>, ICollection<T>, HashSet<T>)
  • ‚úÖ Nullable value types and collections
  • ‚úÖ Circular reference protection for self-referencing entities
  • ‚úÖ N-N relationship patterns with ObjectId collections

‚úÖ Supported Scenarios

The source generator handles a wide range of modern C# patterns, including advanced property configurations and complex relationships:

FeatureSupportDescription
Property Inheritance‚úÖProperties from base classes are automatically included in serialization
Private Setters‚úÖProperties with private set are correctly deserialized using Expression Trees
Init-Only Setters‚úÖProperties with init are supported via runtime compilation
Private Constructors‚úÖDeserialization works even without parameterless public constructor
Advanced Collections‚úÖIEnumerable<T>, ICollection<T>, IList<T>, HashSet<T>, and more
Nullable Value Types‚úÖObjectId?, int?, DateTime? are correctly serialized/deserialized
Nullable Collections‚úÖList<T>?, string? with proper null handling
Unlimited Nesting‚úÖDeeply nested object graphs with circular reference protection
Self-Referencing‚úÖEntities can reference themselves (e.g., Manager property in Employee)
N-N Relationships‚úÖCollections of ObjectIds for efficient document referencing

Example: Advanced Property Patterns

public class Person
{
    // Property inheritance - inherited properties are included
    public ObjectId Id { get; set; }
    
    // Private setter - Expression Trees used for deserialization
    public string Name { get; private set; }
    
    // Init-only setter - Runtime compilation for setting
    public string Email { get; init; }
    
    // Nullable value type - Proper null handling
    public DateTime? BirthDate { get; set; }
    
    // Advanced collection - ICollection<T> recognized
    public ICollection<string> Tags { get; set; }
    
    // Self-referencing - Circular reference protection
    public ObjectId? ManagerId { get; set; }
}

‚ö†Ô∏è Limitations & Design Choices

Some scenarios are handled differently or intentionally excluded:

ScenarioStatusReason
Computed Properties‚ö†Ô∏è ExcludedGetter-only properties without backing fields are intentionally skipped (e.g., FullName => $"{First} {Last}")
Constructor Logic‚ö†Ô∏è BypassedDeserialization uses FormatterServices.GetUninitializedObject() to avoid constructor execution
Constructor Validation‚ö†Ô∏è Not ExecutedValidation logic in constructors won't run during deserialization - use Data Annotations instead
üí° Best Practice: For relationships between entities, prefer referencing (storing ObjectIds) over embedding (full nested objects) to avoid data duplication and maintain consistency.

Example: Referencing vs Embedding

// ‚úÖ GOOD: Reference pattern (recommended)
public class Category
{
    public ObjectId Id { get; set; }
    public string Name { get; set; }
    public List<ObjectId> ProductIds { get; set; }  // N-N via IDs
}

public class Product
{
    public ObjectId Id { get; set; }
    public string Name { get; set; }
    public List<ObjectId> CategoryIds { get; set; }  // N-N via IDs
}

// ‚ö†Ô∏è AVOID: Embedding full objects (data duplication)
public class BadCategory
{
    public ObjectId Id { get; set; }
    public List<Product> Products { get; set; }  // Duplicates product data!
}
